hgr::ParticleSystem Class Reference
[Hierarchical graphics library]

#include <ParticleSystem.h>

Inheritance diagram for hgr::ParticleSystem:

[legend]
List of all members.

Detailed Description

Particle effect.

Can be created directly or from Lua script.

Key features:

  • Variable number of emitters / single system
  • Variable number of particles / emitter
  • All properties can have different random variable value distribution
  • Elastic, scaling, rotating etc. particle sprites are supported.
  • Per particle transparency, color and animation texture frame are supported.
  • Particles can use also user defined shaders.

Particle systems are heavily based on concept of 'domains'. It is a bit abstract, but understanding it is essential for effective usage of the particle systems. On the benefit side once you understand it, using the particle systems becomes very intuitive and orthogonal, as nearly all properties of particle systems are simple defined by setting appropriate value domains for each property.

'Domains' are source ranges for various random values needed by particle systems. Domains can be sources for scalar values, 2D and 3D vectors used in the simulation.

For example by saying that some particle effect has particle initial position domain set as 'Sphere with radius 4' means that the initial positions of new particles are randomized inside sphere which has radius 4. If in turn the particle initial velocity domain is set as Point {-50,0,0} then all particles get initial velocity of -50 along negative X-axis.

With various domains it is easy to make pretty much any kind of particle effect. For example rain could be done by setting position box above sky, and then velocity Point(0,-1,0) and Gravity=-9.8. In addition, ParticleSpriteElasticity could be set above 0 (say, 0.1) to stretch particle bitmap along movement speed - the system is very flexible.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum hgr::ParticleSystem::AnimationType
 

Animation type of particle texture.

Defines how texture frames change over life time of particle effect.

Enumeration values:
ANIM_LOOP  Animation frames are used as normal animation sequence.

Framerate defines how often frame is changed to next one.

ANIM_LIFE  Animation frames are used by particle life time.

Framerate does not affect any way.

ANIM_RANDOM  Animation frames are used randomly.

Framerate defines how often frame is randomized.

ANIM_COUNT  Number of animation types.

enum hgr::ParticleSystem::KillType
 

Kill mode describes how max count limit is maintained.

Enumeration values:
KILL_NONE  No items are killed when max limit is reached.
KILL_OLDEST  Oldest item is killed when max limit is reached.
KILL_RANDOM  Random item is killed when max limit is reached.
KILL_COUNT  Number of kill modes.

enum hgr::ParticleSystem::ViewType
 

View mode of particle sprites.

View mode defines how particles are rotated when camera is tilted.

Enumeration values:
VIEW_CAMERAUP  Particles are facing to camera and bitmaps Y-axis points up in camera space.

VIEW_WORLDUP  Particles are facing to camera and bitmaps Y-axis points up in world space.

VIEW_COUNT  Number of view modes.

void hgr::ParticleSystem::getShaders (  lang::Array< gr::Shader * > &  shaders  )  [virtual]
 

Returns array of shaders used by this visual.

NOTE: Implementation should not clear the list of returned shaders before adding new ones, since shadesr from multiple Visuals might be collected at the same time.

Implements hgr::Visual.
